summary: The U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York today entered a final judgment against defendant Christopher Young, Jr., who was convicted of three counts of aggravated sexual abuse of a child and three counts sodomy on a child, all first-degree felonies.  The court also entered a judgment against Young, ordering him to serve a total of fifteen years to life in prison.  According to the SEC's complaint, filed in federal district court in New York, Young confessed to committing the felonies in April 2014. The complaint alleges that, during the interview, Young told the detective that he had worked from 10 p.m. to 7 a.m., and that he was “hard-working and helped support his family.” The complaint further alleges that the detective told Defendant that he could “relax and put [his] mind at ease” by signing the waiver of rights form, which set forth Defendant’s Miranda rights. The SEC also alleges that Young consented to the entry of a judgment that permanently enjoins him from future violations of the antifraud provisions of Section 17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933 and Section 10(b) the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder, and orders him to pay a $10,000 fine and a $2,139.49 civil penalty. The judgment also imposes a five-year officer-and-director bar against Young.  In a parallel action, the United States Attorney's Office for New York and the Federal Bureau of Investigation today announced criminal charges against Young in connection with the same conduct alleged in the complaint. District Judge's Office against Young for his participation in the alleged misconduct.  Without admitting or denying the allegations of the complaint, the court has agreed to a judgment permanently enjoining him from violating the charged provisions of the federal securities laws, imposing a $25,000 civil penalty, and appointing a receiver to oversee the investigation.
